candidates.title: Migrate to std::future, tokio 0.2 and actix-rt 1.0.0
candidates.body: This is an update to bring the framework up to date with the latest versions of actix-rt, tokio, and futures.

candidates.title: Use std::collections::HashMap instead of hashbrown
candidates.body:
Split from #265 

`std::collections::HashMap`'s implementation has been replaced with `hashbrown::HashMap` implementation in Rust 1.36. Using `std::collections::HashMap` is good because we can reduce dependency.

`hashbrown 0.3.0` uses `fx` algorithm:
> This hash function is very fast for all types of keys, but this algorithm will typically not protect against attacks such as HashDoS.

`std::collections::HashMap` uses `SipHash`:
> While its performance is very competitive for medium sized keys, other hashing algorithms will outperform it for small keys such as integers as well as large keys such as long strings, though those algorithms will typically not protect against attacks such as HashDoS.

I am in favor of using std's default algorithm, but other opinions are welcome.

candidates.title: Add doc-comment to test README examples
candidates.body: (It allowed me to fix an error in the examples btw ;) )

candidates.title: examples chat: Add signal handling in server
candidates.body:
This also serves as an example of how to replace the functionality of
the removed signal actor. An appropriate reference in `CHANGES.md` is
added.

candidates.title: examples chat: Switch to 2018 edition
candidates.body:
This allows eliminating all the `extern crate` statements from the
chat example source code.

candidates.title: Add derive tests for MessageResponse
candidates.body:
Related: https://github.com/actix/actix-derive/pull/14

Awaiting new release of actix-derive before CI tests can pass. I've ran tests using a path dependency to a local clone of actix-derive to make sure the tests pass.

candidates.title: Fix/cleanup deps
candidates.body:
Cleanup of dependencies:
- put tokio-tcp behind the resolver feature
- remove tokio-reactor
- set tokio default-features to false

candidates.title: Migrate to actix-rt
Bump trust-dns-proto to 0.6
candidates.body:
Currently actix ends up pulling both 0.5 and 0.6:
```
trust-dns-proto v0.5.0
└── actix v0.7.10 (/home/fabrice/dev/actix)

trust-dns-proto v0.6.3
└── trust-dns-resolver v0.10.3
    └── actix v0.7.10 (/home/fabrice/dev/actix)
```
Moving to 0.6 prevents that.

candidates.title: Add weak referenced type `WeakAddr<A>` for actors
Update crossbeam-channel to 0.3 and parking_lot to 0.7
candidates.body: As far as I can see, this should be a minor semver change. I hope I got the migration to the new crossbeam-channel API right so that the new code has the same behavior as the previous version.

candidates.title: Updating trust-dns-resolver dependency to version 0.10.
candidates.body:
trust-dns-resolver 0.10.0 has additional, useful options (e.g., max TTL) that can be passed in via ResolverOpts. These newer options are not available in trust-dns-resolver 0.9.1, which is what Actix currently depends on. This pull request updates Actix to depend on trust-dns-resolver 0.10.

What trust-dns-resolver used to call ResolverFuture is now called AsyncResolver. When creating an AsyncResolver, instead of being given a Future which must be waited on to construct the Resolver, you are immediately given an AsyncResolver, plus a background task that must be spawned to perform DNS lookups (https://docs.rs/trust-dns-resolver/0.10.0/trust_dns_resolver/struct.AsyncResolver.html). This pull request essentially does the renaming of types, plus spawns the background task.

candidates.title: Update uuid to 0.7
candidates.body: Updates uuid to the latest release (0.6 to 0.7) which renamed `hyphenated()` to `to_hyphenated_ref()` and `simple()` to `to_simple_ref()`.
